item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_

@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

It does that because it’s unsigned. If you sign the applet, and then the user accepts the certificate then that will go away.

item.title: Button
item.dc:creator: @Hiaburi Hiaburi
item.description:
@Hiaburi wrote:

yea it is, and it didnt work it still sais applet window at the bottom in a gray section
heres what i got so far

    public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent ae) {
    JFrame popup = new JFrame("Instructions");
	popup.setLayout(null);
	Toolkit toolkit = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit();
    int i = toolkit.getScreenSize().width/2;
    int j = toolkit.getScreenSize().height/2;
		int width = 200;
		int height = 200;
		popup.setLocation(i-(width/2), j-(height/2));
        popup.setSize(width, height);
		JLabel label = new JLabel("test");
		label.setBounds(10, 30, 60, 10);
		popup.add(label);
		
	popup.setVisible(true);
    }

oh well settign the layout to null fixed the text problem, now it goes were i want it but it still sais java applet frame or whatever at the bottom

Read full topic

item.title: Button
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Alright,
For the popup frame/panel, call setLayout(null) on it.

Then JLabel lbl = new JLabel(“Text”);
lbl.setBounds(x, y, width, height);
container.add(lbl);

Do setLayout right afer you initialize the frame var.

Read full topic

item.title: Button
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

container.add(readButton);
Container being the frame or panel you have everything in.

And like BobDole said, if it is a subclass of either of those, you can just do
add(readButton);
Unless you’re adding it elsewhere.

Read full topic

item.title: Button
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

What are you adding the button to? If you don’t have a superclass of Applet or Panel/JPanel, you need to specify what you’re adding the button to.

A bit more code would help us get you an answer.

Read full topic
